title: Old receipt font??
content:
Hi all!  
I have a very hard time finding wich font this is.  
I've scanned it from an old receipt, and the letters u can se is: QJ\*6123 MN 6,9 p/P

I've "restored" the QJ\*6 letters in photoshop, all the letters should look like that but the others is due to bad scanner/receipt...

What i've found is that it almost looks like some kind of Gothic font.. but none of them is like the letter J.. Please help me!

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Wich\_Font.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20110902120940/http:/typophile.com/files/Wich_Font.jpg) | 20.51 KB |
author: p2h

comments.content:
I don't think this is a digital font for a computer. I think this is a built-in typeface for a receipt printer. The closest digital font I can think of is FF SubVario or SubMono (see [http://www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&startro...](http://web.archive.org/web/20110902120940/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&startrow=1&records=&currpage=1&totalrecords=30&displayfontid=FF.11053.0.0&fontRendererText=QJ*6123+MN9+p%2FP "http://www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&startrow=1&records=&currpage=1&totalrecords=30&displayfontid=FF.11053.0.0&fontRendererText=QJ\*6123+MN9+p%2FP"))

- Mike Yanega

Yes I think so too. The theory that it's not a digital font for a computer...  
The font you suggested is close but not perfect :D Im thinking of creating the font in Macromedia Fontographer. Maybe that the best solution?

I would always ask myself whether it is important to have an exact reproduction of such a typeface. If your answer is 'YES", and If you have the time and skill to reproduce a mechanical printer type, that is a fine way.

- Mike Yanega
